title: Split parameters to the KDF
body:
It would be best practice to treat G(x) as a salt for input to HKDF-Extract.

Separately, I noticed that this exposes a problem that you might consider separately: HKDF-Extract produces an output that is the same size as the underlying hash output.  Your text assumes that both the PRF and the KDF produce an output of size L.  That's not necessarily the case, even for HKDF, since HKDF produces output of arbitrary size.

Rather than try to address that, I would recommend that you use HKDF more directly unless there is any reason that you need to maintain flexibility.

title: Updates from Stanislaw's comments
body:
1. First of all, it seems important to state explicitly that such
measures as relying on feeding private keys (or signatures created with
them) to PRNGs can be considered as last line of defense only, for
cases when no other entropy sources are available at all.

2. Secondly, since DSA/ECDSA/EC-RDSA signatures require randomness
themselves, it seems reasonable to mention that it would be better to
discuss keys of deterministic signatures (e.g., RSA, if not to consider
PSS) and RSA signatures regarding the provided construction - not
DSA/ECDSA/EC-RDSA. The signature output is not available to anyone, its
only fed to a PRF, but anyway the usage of signature schemes requiring
randomness themselves to provide randomness does not seem to be the best
idea.

3. If an equipment is used in a hostile environment, where side-channel
adversaries should be considered, extra operations with private keys must
be taken into account when estimating lifetimes of keys.

4. When a private key is used for such kind of technological signatures,
Id prefer that the signed data
a. would include timestamps and/or counters
b. would include some data that is specific for a particular device  to
prevent the existence of equivalent PRNGs in different devices dealing
with a single private key (e.g. if one HSM with a server private key is
used from several servers or for the cases of cloned virtual machines).
c. would have some kind of structured form like This is data signed only
for the purpose of randomness generations (input parameters = [timestamp],
[counter]).  so these technical signatures can never be used by any
attacker for other purposes (and to prevent all kinds of signing oracle
here)  even despite using them only as PRF inputs.

5. All protocols that exploit this kind of entropy based on long-term
private keys should be analyzed specifically together with a specific
signature scheme, PRF and PRNG  to prevent any influence on security
(e.g. if PRF(KDF(G(x) || Sig(sk, tag)), tag) is used for generation of
random values for ECDSA signatures on the key sk, for the cases when G(x)
degenerates).
